captions.text:
00:02
COMM: While most people would get eaten walking

into a lion's den, Shandor Larenty is completely
at ease. The 18-year-old enjoys a unique relationship

with 30 of the huge predators, as he plays
with, grooms and even massages them.

00:19
Over the years, Shandor has built up a very
special relationship with Zaru.

00:22
Shandor: He absolutely loves me and I absolutely

love him. He loves being- his mane being mess
up, jumping up on trees, going for walks,

but his favourite thing he loves me to do
to him is massage his feet. It's one of his
absolute favourite things.

00:39
COMM: Here at the lion park in Pretoria, South

Africa, the teenager is becoming a lion trainer,
just like his father Alex.

00:46
Shandor: About 7 years ago I started coming

with my dad to work and it kind of took off
from there. I've grown up doing it, it's something

I'm used to, it's something I love doing.
The trust they put into you to actually be

able to do this stuff you do with them is
absolutely amazing.

01:04
A lot of the lions that I actually work with

were born when I actually started here, so
I've basically grown up with them. We're used
to each other, friends with each other basically.

01:12
COMM: Shandor's training comes under the watchful

eye of his father Alex, who's been a lion
trainer for over 30 years.

01:18
Shandor: Dad, can I have some meat?

01:20
Alex: I've taken Shandor to see the animals

the minute he could walk, you know, we went
with little bits of food to feed the elephants

and feed the giraffes and stuff like that,
so from day 1, it was on go.

01:31
COMM: And like any apprentice, Shandor is
only to keen to learn from his mentor.

01:35
Shandor: My dad is my mentor. Everything that

I've actually learnt about working with animals
has come from him. His information has come

from previous generations and he's had some
of the best trainers in the world.

01:45
COMM: Today, Shandor and Alex are exercising
one of their star lions.

01:50
Shandor: We're taking Columbus, which is one

of our big male lions - he was in a lot of
movies and stuff - we're taking him for a

bit of a walk. We're hoping he's not in a
bad mood. Maybe he is. You never know.

02:05
Alex: I do fear for his safety sometimes,

but then that's what I'm there for, just to
correct it. Say, "Hey son, don't do that,

because that's one of the things to be careful
of", you know? There's things that I see sometimes

that he doesn't see because I've got more
experience.

02:20
That's how big a lion is and people don't
realise how big they actually are.

02:24
COMM: And Shandor himself is only too aware
of the dangers of his chosen profession.

02:28
Shandor: These animals are extremely powerful.

A male lion weighs up to 250 kilograms. If
that weight hits you, if he jumps on you,

you're straight over. They have a jaw pressure
of 1 ton per square inch and those teeth are

very long so when they go into you, you're
gonna know all about it."

02:42
Shandor: I don't fear for my safety. It's

not something that you should think about
while you're busy working with the animals.

02:48
COMM: And with the guidance of his father,
Shandor is convinced he will achieve his dream.

02:53
Shandor: Attack of the baby lion... attack
of the baby lion

title: Lion Tamer Teenager In South Africa

American actress Melanie Griffith also grew up with Lions and their family 
once made a documentary of their Lion pets but many of the film crew were 
injured during the making of it. The level of bond between 18 year old 
Shandor and Zavu the Lion is akin to the other Lion Whisperer Kevin 
Richardson also in South Africa. Lions are truly majestic in their spirit, 
their powerful presence and the deep bond that exists between them within 
their pride.﻿
